captions.text:
More than one and a half billion people use
the internet every day, and they search for
just about everything you can imagine.

We’re all about that curiosity here at SciShow.
Which is why we’ve worked with Google and

YouTube to answer ten of the most popular
questions searched for on the internet.
This is The World’s Most Asked Questions.

Today’s question is apparently on a lot
of people's minds: How much water do should
I drink a day?

Well, it’s helpful to keep in mind that
you basically ARE water -- it’s your body’s

principal chemical component. The average
adult is made up of about 65% bodily fluid.

And you are that way, because pretty much
all of your body’s major systems depend

on water to function. Water regulates your
body temperature and dissolves minerals and

nutrients, and helps carry oxygen to your
cells. Your body is what scientists call an

aqueous solution - all the chemical reactions
that happen inside of you that make you you
happen in water.

But still, exactly how much you need depends
on who you are, and what you’re up to.

Your age and weight and diet and level of
activity, and even what kind of climate you
live in, all affect your hydration requirements.

If you’re running marathons in August, for
example, you’re obviously going to need

a lot more water than if you’re reading
on the couch all day.

But, OK, you’re looking for a number. I
get that. You probably heard a lot of them,
so you're asking Google.

And the guideline you’ve probably heard
is that you should drink eight, 8-ounce glasses,
or about 1.9 liters of water per day.

And no one’s really sure where that advice
came from -- even though everyone, up to and
including doctors, has repeated it.

But according to the Institute of Medicine,
the average woman should consume 2.7 liters

-- that’s 91 ounces -- of water a day, and
men 3.7 liters, or 125 ounces a day.

Now, they point out that you actually get
about 20% of your daily water intake from

the food you eat -- more than that if you’re
eating a lot of fruit and vegetables -- but

still, the so-called “eight by eight”
approach might not be enough to supply the
other 80%

In the end, it’s best to use your common
sense, and listen to your body. It’s a good

idea to keep your eye on your pee -- you want
it to be a light yellow color -- but really,

just drink when you’re thirsty, and don’t
overthink it. Really, don't overthink it.

According to the results of our non-scientific
SciShow survey, 67% of you drink three or

more glasses of water per day, but those of
you who said you have no idea what you're

doing here on earth are more dehydrated than
the rest of the people. So maybe just relax,
drink a glass of water. You'll figure it out.

Of all the fascinating questions in the world,
what question do you want answered most? Let

us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the comments
below and we will answer the best questions

in a new video at the end of the month. And
don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ and
watch the other videos this week.

title: World’s Most Asked Questions: How Much Water Should I Drink a Day?

comments.text:
You're still quite young. I'm 32 and the 'water making me nauseous' thing 
never really went away entirely. Sometimes I'll still feel it if I drink 
too much as once or the water isn't a good quality. Like, I hate the taste 
of regular Arrowhead water. The quality is extremely poor and it's obvious. 
However, I do enjoy their sparkling flavored waters. The best kind of water 
we should all be drinking has a high PH balance and, preferably, ozonated. 
Ozonated bottled water can be hard to find and ozonating machines can be 
quite costly. But it's worth it for good health. If I recall correctly, 
Costco's Kirkland water is ozonated. Walgreen's brand water used to be, as 
well, but they recently got rid of it for some reason.

There are many things you can do to make water more palatable. Try adding 
fresh lemon juice, especially in the morning. Some people like to add 
cucumber slices. Lime juice is a good choice, too. You can add the essence 
of any fruit to water.

comments.text:
Summary: To be precise, this 2 liter is the amount of urine an average 
person should pee in a day for healthy kidney.


"2 Liters per day" actually comes from requirement of the kidneys. 
Basically,
1) Multiply "the average blood volume pass trough kidney of an average 
person" with "the average amount of urea produced from unite volume of 
blood volume passing trough kidney".
2) Calculate the minimum required water to dissolve the urea which is 
produced by this average person in one day.

In our animal physiology course, we calculated it to be around 2 Liter per 
day per this average person with out knowing anything about him or her 
other than the above mentioned average values. This value excludes the 
water lost by evaporation or sweating.

To be precise, this 2 liter is the amount of urine an average person should 
pee in a day for healthy kidney.

Every type of water you take (fruit, hot meal, beer, tap water) is 
accountable for water intake. On the other hand, you must add more water to 
remove some other dissolved matter which are filtered in your kidney. For 
example, the caffeine, which is taken with your coffee or coke, requires 
much more additional water to be peed out.  ﻿

comments.text:
What this video fails to mention and most of the people who carry water 
with themselves everywhere don't seem to realize is that beverages other 
than pure water are giving water in addition to the small amounts of other 
stuff in them. It's not just food that adds water. Coffee and tea are 
mostly water. Wine is mostly water. Beer is mostly water. Soft drinks are 
mostly water. Even hard liquor has a lot of water. If someone drinks a 20 
oz. coffee and a 12 oz. bottle of beer, there's half of the 64 ounces that 
"somebody" decided we "need" every day and lots of gullible people 
a.)believed and b.)mistook to mean they had to drink that much pure water 
in addition to whatever water they got from other sources.﻿

comments.author: Sasha Blouse

comments.text:
I've seen a number of people talking smack about this miniseries SciShow is 
doing, saying that it's just answering a bunch of questions that anyone 
could find the answer to with but a few seconds and the internet.
I personally find it less about the answer and more about the question. If 
it's one of the most common questions in the world, you'd reckon a majority 
of the asking party has found the answer. This is really more about what 
the average person wants to know: there are a lot of people asking about 
this, so here's everything you need to know. Additionally, there's the 
factor of learning what the most asked questions are. I would have guessed 
"What is the meaning of life?", but something like this never occurred to 
me as such a common question. As a last note, if a question is frequently 
asked, then people are frequently in the dark about its answer. A lot of 
people will ask these questions in the future, as the past search history 
has shown. Having a one-stop shop for all you need to know can be useful.
In the end, this series helps those who know the answer, those who want to 
know the answer, and those who don't even know the question yet.﻿
